resources.string: Do you want to add a new product?
Do you want to edit the product?
Do you want to remove the product?
Do you want to add a new recipe?
Do you want to edit the recipe?
Do you want to remove the recipe?
Do you want to create a new shopping list?
Do you want to create a new export file?
Do you want to import data from this file? All your previous data will be removed!
This product cannot be removed because it is used in a recipe!
At least one item is required!
At least one product has no set average size!
Sum of nutrients in product cannot be higher than its average size!
Name of the author is empty!
Content of this step is empty!
Name of the file to export is empty!

A section presenting the user with statistics regarding the database used in the Plate Handler app.\n\nThe fragment Recipe Number defines the number of recipes added by the author, while Product Number expresses the sum of all saved products and those added by default to the database after the first launch of the app.

A section showing a list of six recently viewed recipes available in the app.\n\nThe individual items are ordered from the last shown recipe. Choosing one of them takes the user to a specific page of the recipe.

A section allowing the user to add a photo representing the approximate appearance of the currently created recipe. It is not a required part of the creation process to be completed.\n\nThe user can select a specific image from the gallery by selecting the button on the left side. If the photo does not meet the requirements, it can be removed using the button on the right side.

A section allowing the user to supplement main data regarding the recipe. It is a required part to be completed and cannot be left empty.\n\nThe Name text field stands for the name given to the recipe, while Author text field describes the creator of a particular dish.

A section allowing the user to specify information about the recipe, allowing easier identification of dishes among other functions. Data is set here using various types of control views.

In the Servings fragment, the user can increase or decrease the number of portions allocated in the recipe by using the plus and minus buttons.

The Time fragment informs about the time period of preparation of the recipe, which is set by clicking the special button (cannot be equal to zero minutes).

The Difficulty and Spiciness fragments contain progress bars through which the user can increase the level of difficulty of the recipe and how spicy the dish is.

The drop-down views appearing in Cuisine and Type fragments allow user to choose the country from which the recipe comes from and in which category it belongs.

The last fragment named Preferences allows the user to select the item representing the preferences in terms of composition of the recipe, depending on whether it contains meat or is vegetarian.

A section presenting the user with main information regarding the selected recipe.

The Servings fragment represents the number of portions allocated in the recipe, the Time fragment shows how much time is needed to prepare the dish, while Difficulty expresses the level of difficulty of the recipe.

The spiciness of the dish is represented by icons in the Spiciness section. One pepper means a mild dish, while four peppers mean a super hot one.

The Cuisine, Type and Preferences fragments characterize the country from which the recipe comes from, which category it falls in and whether it is vegetarian or not in that order. In addition, this data is marked with matching icons.

A section showing a list of ingredients included in a selected recipe. Each item contains basic information about a specific ingredient, consistent with those set at the stage of recipe creation.

At the top of the specific item is the name of the product used as the ingredient, the quantity combined with the measure of the ingredient is located below it, and on the left there is the icon representing the type of the product.

In the upper right corner of each ingredient there is a checkbox, which after being clicked informs the user about ingredient being used while executing the recipe.

A section showing a list of preparation steps of the recipe. Each item contains basic information about a specific step, in line with those set at the stage of creating the recipe.

At the top of the specific item there is the number of the step representing the order in which steps should be followed, and below it the content in the form of instructions to follow is located.

In the upper right corner of each step there is a checkbox, which after being clicked informs the user about completing the given step while executing the recipe.

A section presenting information about total amount of calories in a selected recipe to the user, expressed in kilocalories. All calorific values of individual ingredients have been summed up here.

The Total Calories fragment determines the total amount of calories in a given recipe, while Per Serving fragment expresses the number of calories allocated to exactly one portion of a given meal.

If at least one product belonging to an ingredient does not have its information about composition set, the caloric data will be empty.

A section presenting information about total amount of calories in a selected recipe to the user, expressed in kilojoules. All calorific values of individual ingredients have been summed up here.

The Total Calories fragment determines the total amount of calories in a given recipe, while Per Serving fragment expresses the number of calories allocated to exactly one portion of a given meal.

If at least one product belonging to an ingredient does not have its information about composition set, the caloric data will be empty.

A section showing a list of ingredients for a selected recipe, along with their calories. With this solution, the user can find out exactly what values are included in the summed up calorie composition of the entire recipe.

Each individual item contains basic information about a specific ingredient, consistent with that available on the recipe page.

The left side of each item shows the calorific value of the ingredient, expressed in both kilocalories and kilojoules. If the composition information has not been set in the product used in the ingredient, the calorie data will be empty.

A section allowing the user to specify search settings regarding recipe selection. Individual changes are made here by using the switches, available in every fragment.

If the user selects a switch in the Alphabetical fragment, then the list of recipes will be displayed in alphabetical order.

By clicking the switch in the Favorite fragment, a restriction is introduced so that only recipes marked with a star are visible.

After selecting the switch in the subsequent fragments the drop-down views will appear for setting further restrictions on recipe searching.

If the user wants to lift the restrictions on displayed items, the specific switches need to be unchecked.

A section allowing the user to add new items to set data for individual ingredients in a recipe.\n\nThe user can increase the number of items by clicking the Add New Ingredient button. The following items will appear in the list in the Set Ingredient Data section down below.

A section allowing the user to specify information about individual ingredients of a recipe. Data is set here using various types of control views available for each item.

The Amount text field signifies a number representing the quantity of a specific ingredient with a certain measure, which is required to correctly complete the dish. Its value must be greater than zero.

In the Measure fragment, the drop-down view allows the user to choose the correct measure of the ingredient.

Depending on whether there are products in the app, the Product fragment may contain a drop-down view that allows the user to select an available product as a part of the ingredient in the recipe. The following items cannot use the same product repeatedly.

The plus button located on the right side of each item allows the user to add a new product if the required element does not exist in the drop-down view. By clicking it the user will open the product creation page.

On the left side of each item there is a cross out icon, which will delete the item after clicking it.

A section that allows the user to add new recipe preparation steps.\n\nThe user can increase the number of items by clicking the Add New Step button, and a new page will open. After completing certain information, subsequent items will appear in the list in the Current Steps section down below.

A section showing a list of previously added steps of the recipe. If a specific step does not meet the requirements, it can be changed here.

In the upper right corner of each step there is a cross out icon and by clicking it the user will delete the following item.

Next to it on the left is the edit button that allows the user to change the content of the selected step.

If no steps are added, the list will be empty.

A section allowing the user to complete the content regarding a specific step of the recipe. It is a required part to be completed and cannot be left empty.\n\nThe Step text field signyfies a detailed description of the instructions required to complete the recipe at a given stage.

A section allowing the user to add a photo representing the approximate appearance of the currently created product. It is not a required part of the creation process to be completed.\n\nThe user can select a specific image from the gallery by selecting the button on the left side. If the photo does not meet the requirements, it can be removed using the button on the right side.

A section allowing the user to set primary data of the product.

The Name text field indicates the name given to the product. It is a required part to be completed and cannot be left empty.

The Type fragment contains a drop-down view that allows the user to choose the category of the product.

A section allowing the user to specify composition values of the product. The text fields may remain empty, however, this prevents the app from calculating calories for both the product and the recipe in which it was used.\n\nThe Average Size text field specifies the average total weight of a particular product, while Carbohydrates, Proteins and Fats fields characterize the amount of nutrients the product includes (their sum must not exceed the total size). The unit of each value depends on the previously set type of the product (grams or milliliters).

A section presenting the user with information about the composition of a given product, expressed in grams or milliliters (depending on the product type).

The Carbohydrates, Proteins and Fats fragments determine the nutrient values of the product, while the Other fragment expresses the remaining composition, obtained after subtracting nutrient values from total weight.

In the Percentage Charts of Nutrients fragment there are two charts - bar chart shows the percentage values of each nutrient separately, while the pie chart presents the percentage values of the sum of all the nutrients compared to the remaining composition of the product.

If composition data of the product has not been set, the calorific data will be empty.

A section presenting the user with information about calories in a selected product, expressed in kilocalories.

The Carbohydrates, Proteins and Fats fragments specify the calorific values for individual nutrients in the product, while the Total Calories expresses the sum of all calorific values of the product. 

If composition data of the product has not been set, the calorific data will be empty.

A section presenting the user with information about calories in a selected product, expressed in kilojoules.

The Carbohydrates, Proteins and Fats fragments specify the calorific values for individual nutrients in the product, while the Total Calories expresses the sum of all calorific values of the product. 

If composition data of the product has not been set, the calorific data will be empty.

A section allowing the user to specify search settings regarding product selection. Individual changes are made here by using the switches, available in every fragment.

If the user selects a switch in the Alphabetical fragment, then the list of products will be displayed in alphabetical order.

After selecting the switch in the Type fragment, a drop-down view will appear for setting a search restriction based on selected type of the product.

If the user wants to lift the restrictions on displayed items, the specific switches need to be unchecked.

A section presenting the user with information about the current shopping list. If the shopping list does not exist, data will be empty.

The Shopping Date fragment specifies the exact day the shopping list was created, while the Shopping State expresses how many shopping items were crossed out from the list.

The user can create a new shopping list by clicking the Create New List button, and the list creation view will open.

A section presenting a shopping list with items placed one after the other. They can be crossed out by clicking them, so the user do not have to remember what items are already bought.\n\nIf the user has crossed out an item by mistake, the error can be fixed by clicking the item again.

A section allowing the user to add new elements to set data for individual shopping list items.

The user can increase the number of items by clicking the Add New Item button. The following items will appear in the list in the Set Shopping Item Data section down below.

To ensure user convenience, there is an option to immediately add all ingredients of a specific recipe as shopping list items by clicking the Choose Recipe button and selecting the appropriate recipe in the newly opened view.

A section allowing the user to specify information about individual items of the shopping list. Data setting is done here using the various control view available for each of the items.

The Amount text field indicates a number representing the quantity of a specific item to buy with a certain measure. Its value must be greater than zero.

In the Measure fragment, the drop-down view allows the user to select the correct measure for the shopping list element.

In the Name text field, the entered value is the name of the shopping list item and cannot be left empty.

On the left side of each item, there is a cross out icon, which removes the item after clicking it.

A section allowing the user to specify a name of the file containing exported database from the app. This data is a required part to be completed and cannot be left empty.\n\nThis value must be entered in the Name text field. Appending the file extension name to the end is unnecessary, by default it will be set as xls after the export operation is completed.

A section presenting guidelines to the user regarding saving the database in the form of an export file. Some parts of data will be omitted.\n\nThe Saved Data fragment specifies exactly what data groups will be saved in the generated xls file, while the Unsaved Data fragment lists the information, which will be unsaved and deleted from the app after the import operation is completed.

A section showing a list of files created as part of the export operation. They contain specific information from the database of the app and are used to import said data.\n\nFor each item, the number of recipes and products it contains is determined. After selecting a specific file, import operation is performed, which involves deleting the current data of the app.

A section presenting the user with information about the author of the Plate Handler app.\n\nThe Developer fragment contains the name, surname and nickname of the author. Information about libraries and icon used by the creator of the app can be found in the sections below.

A section showing a list of libraries used in the Plate Handler app. Each item contains basic information about a particular library, starting with its name at the top of the item.\n\nThe Author fragment defines who the author of the library is, the Version fragment expresses the identifier of the library version used in the app, while the License fragment describes which license covers each library.

A section showing a list of packs with icons used in the Plate Handler app. Each item contains basic information about a particular pack, starting with its name at the top of the item.\n\nThe Attribution fragment shows the exact contents of the attribution about the author of the icon pack, the License fragment describes what license the package is covered by, while the Amount fragment determines the number of icons from the given pack used in the app.

A section showing a list of fonts used in the logo and the icon of the Plate Handler app. Each item contains basic information about a particular font, starting with its name at the top of the item.\n\nThe Author fragment defines who the author of the font is, the Version fragment expresses the identifier of the font version used in the logo and the icon of the app, while the License fragment describes which license covers each font.
Icon on the side of the item
Button to increase number of servings
Button to decrease number of servings
Button to set time of the recipe
Button to add the new product
